<article class="post-4874 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-2nd-year-mbbs category-study-guides ast-article-single" id="post-4874" itemtype="https://schema.org/CreativeWork" itemscope="itemscope" style="height: auto !important;">

	
	
<div class="ast-post-format- single-layout-1 ast-no-date-box" style="height: auto !important;">

	
	
	
	<div class="entry-content clear" itemprop="text" style="height: auto !important;">

		
		<div class="td_block_wrap tdb_single_subtitle tdi_55 td-pb-border-top td_block_template_1" data-td-block-uid="tdi_55" style="height: auto !important;">
<div class="tdb-block-inner td-fix-index" style="height: auto !important;">
<p>Second professional is long and exams would feel tough as the syllabus is MIGHTY, but everything would be good at the end. Also, do not forget to enjoy. The memories you would make in Second year are the things you are going to cherish forever.</p><div class="code-block code-block-1" style="margin: 8px 0; clear: both;">
<script async="" src="https://pagead2.googlesyndication.com/pagead/js/adsbygoogle.js"></script>
<ins class="adsbygoogle" style="display: block; text-align: center; height: 280px;" data-ad-layout="in-article" data-ad-format="fluid" data-ad-client="ca-pub-2086012481223364" data-ad-slot="5467673894" data-adsbygoogle-status="done" data-ad-status="unfilled"><div id="aswift_0_host" style="border: none; height: 280px; width: 793px; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; position: relative; visibility: visible; background-color: transparent; display: inline-block; overflow: visible;"><iframe id="aswift_0" name="aswift_0" style="left:0;position:absolute;top:0;border:0;width:793px;height:280px;min-height:auto;max-height:none;min-width:auto;max-width:none;" sandbox="allow-forms allow-popups allow-popups-to-escape-sandbox allow-same-origin allow-scripts allow-top-navigation-by-user-activation" width="793" height="280" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" vspace="0" hspace="0" allowtransparency="true" scrolling="no" allow="attribution-reporting; run-ad-auction" src="https://googleads.g.doubleclick.net/pagead/ads?client=ca-pub-2086012481223364&output=html&h=280&slotname=5467673894&adk=1696468195&adf=1447325909&pi=t.ma~as.5467673894&w=793&fwrn=4&fwrnh=0&lmt=1771139559&rafmt=1&armr=3&format=793x280&url=https%3A%2F%2Fmedical-junction.com%2Fmbbs-2nd-year-pathology-important-questions&fwr=0&rpe=1&resp_fmts=3&aieuf=1&aicrs=1&uach=WyIiLCIiLCIiLCIiLCIiLG51bGwsMCxudWxsLCIiLG51bGwsMF0.&abgtt=9&dt=1771139559418&bpp=113&bdt=600&idt=235&shv=r20260211&mjsv=m202602100101&ptt=9&saldr=aa&abxe=1&cookie_enabled=1&eoidce=1&correlator=3035189541300&frm=20&pv=2&rplot=4&u_tz=0&u_his=2&u_h=600&u_w=800&u_ah=600&u_aw=800&u_cd=24&u_sd=1&dmc=8&adx=55&ady=558&biw=1280&bih=1280&scr_x=0&scr_y=0&eid=95378429%2C95382730%2C31096721%2C95383312&oid=2&pvsid=5591719094841939&tmod=1354785198&uas=0&nvt=1&fc=640&brdim=680%2C570%2C680%2C570%2C800%2C0%2C780%2C580%2C1280%2C1280&vis=1&rsz=%7C%7CEe%7C&abl=CS&pfx=0&fu=128&bc=31&bz=0.61&pgls=CAA.&ifi=1&uci=a!1&fsb=1&dtd=277" data-google-container-id="a!1" tabindex="0" title="Advertisement" aria-label="Advertisement" data-google-query-id="CKSvuIL52pIDFce_fwQdkbU9_A" data-load-complete="true"></iframe></div></ins>
<script>
     (adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({});
</script></div>

<p>Charles Darwin’s theory of natural selection can be very well applied to Medical stream as the one who is fittest to cope up with such enormous amount of inhumane pressures survive. It was not to scare you but to make you alert for what’s coming.</p>
<p>Second year of MBBS is the year you spend in college when you have settled well at the new place with the new people but not able to settle with the course pressure as it just gets amplified as compared to the previous year.</p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Mistakes to avoid in MBBS Second year :</strong></span></p>
<p>First of all, Second professional is <strong>not honeymoon period</strong>. Its better you understand this early.</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Wrong selection of books</strong>: Don’t be hasty while buying the book. Wait for a week or more, consult with other students and especially seniors and try to select and follow Standard books only. Below in the article you will find about the books to follow. Keep this in mind that whichever book you buy and start reading and highlighting, you will have to use the same in future too.</li>
<li><strong>Not touching the books in initial months: </strong>Before the curriculum changed and second year had 3 semesters, first semester was called as ‘Honeymoon semester.’ Students usually didn’t dare touch books for a whole semester and used to regret in later months. Though the new curriculum has shortened the duration by 1 semester, student are going to avoid studying and that’s probably not good.</li>
<li><strong>PG Preperations:</strong> Many students start PG Preparation and get so serious that they prioritize it above their MBBS Second year course. Though its recommended to start PG preparation from this time only but with maintaining balance with second year course being the first priority.</li>
<li><strong>Clinical postings</strong>: I was one of those fools who was too irregular in attending clinical postings. You can be a doctor anyway but attending postings are of utmost importance if you want to be a Good Doctor. You need to run behind seniors and actively participate in postings because teachers wont be going to teach you much actively considering you as a novice.</li>
<li>For the nerds especially, don’t stay stuck inside the books. Do make memories as the future is going to be more harsh and these are the memories you are going to cherish in the coming future.</li>
</ol>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>How to study Pathology?</strong></span></p>
<p>Pathology is the king of 2nd professional subjects. Not denying this fact, Pathology is the base for your future. Whatever you want to pursue, knowledge of pathology is a must! Especially for studying medicine, knowledge of Pathology with Physiology is of utmost importance.</p>
<ul>
<li>Make notes from 2–3 books and make your own answers.</li>
<li>Make your own flowcharts and draw as many as possible in your theory exams.</li>
<li>Do solve previous year University papers to prepare well for your professional exams.</li>
<li>Most Important : Stay in touch with your Seniors & get important topics marked in your textbook to be safe from Pre exam Hassle.</li>
<li>Follow standard books if you can.</li>
<li>Take help of Video Lectures. There are a bunch of good ones available now.</li>
<li>Do read first 7 chapters of Robbin’s Pathology.</li>
<li>Integrate with Pharmacology and Physiology.</li>
<li>Remember, if you want to be a good doctor and ace in Medicine in Final year, you need to start studying pathology from the start of semester and at least revise it one more time.</li>
</ul>
<p>Credit : Medstribune</p>
</div>
</div>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">CELLULAR INJURY</h3>
<h5>Long Questions</h5>
<ol>
<li>Necrosis , types and examples, fate of necrosed area, difference between apoptosis and necrosis</li>
<li>Define apoptosis, what are the cause of apoptosis. Write about the biochemical features and mechanisms of apoptosis. Add a note on deregulated apoptosis</li>
<li>Types of degeneration, pathology of organ affected by fatty changes, add a note on fat stains</li>
</ol>
<h5>Short Questions</h5>
<ol>
<li>Write about cell injury and write briefly about hyperplasia with suitable examples</li>
<li>Cellular swelling</li>
<li>Necrosis</li>
<li>Gangrenous necrosis</li>
<li>Fat necrosis</li>
<li>Tissue necrosis- Morphological patterns</li>
<li>Caseous necrosis</li>
<li>Definition and characteristic of types of necrosis</li>
<li>Free radical cell injury</li>
<li>Morphological changes in apoptosis</li>
<li>Mechanism of apoptosis</li>
<li>Classify pigments and write about lipofuscins</li>
<li>Hemosiderin deposits in the diseases</li>
<li>Difference between the dysplastic and metastatic calcification</li>
<li>Write about dystrophic and metastatic calcifications</li>
<li>Pathological calcification</li>
<li>Metastatic calcification</li>
<li>Define hyperplasia and give two examples</li>
<li>Define atrophy. Give two examples to physiological atrophy</li>
<li>Mention 4 nuclear changes in necrosis</li>
<li>Types of necrosis with examples</li>
<li>Enumerate four examples for metastatic calcification</li>
<li>Enlist two common stains used to demonstrate fat in tissues</li>
</ol>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">INFLAMMATION</h3>
<h5>Long Questions</h5>
<ol>
<li>Define Inflammation. Enumerate the cellular events in acute inflammation.</li>
<li>Discuss in detail the mechanism of Chemotaxis and Phagocytosis. Enlist the common defects in Leukocyte functions</li>
<li>Define inflammation, write in detail about the vascular and cellular changes in inflammation</li>
<li>Chemical mediators of acute inflammation and their actions</li>
</ol>
<h5>Short Questions</h5>
<ol>
<li>Vascular Changes in acute inflammation</li>
<li>Leucocyte endothelium adhesion molecules</li>
<li>Chemotaxis</li>
<li>Chemical mediators of inflammatiom</li>
<li>Role of arachidonic metabolites in inflammation</li>
<li>Chemokines</li>
<li>Leukotrienes</li>
<li>Cytokines</li>
<li>Write about the outcomes of acute inflammation</li>
<li>Different types of giant cells with morphology and examples</li>
<li>Granulomatous inflammation</li>
<li>Granuloma</li>
<li>Leukemoid reaction</li>
<li>Two difference between exudate and transudate</li>
<li>Acute phase reactants</li>
<li>Name four cell derived mediators of inflammation</li>
<li>Four systemic effects of inflammation</li>
<li>Different types of giant cells</li>
<li>Two examples of acute phase proteins</li>
<li>Mast cells</li>
</ol>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">TISSUE RENEWAL AND REPAIR</h3>
<h5>Long Questions</h5>
<ol>
<li>Define repair, process of repair, factors influencing repair</li>
<li>Wound healing second intention, difference between the first and second intention, factor influencing it</li>
</ol>
<h5>Short Questions</h5>
<ol>
<li>Stem cells in tissue homeostasis</li>
<li>Factors influencing wound healing</li>
<li>Healing by second intention</li>
<li>Factors influencing wound healing</li>
<li>Systemic factors that influence wound healing</li>
<li>Types of wound healing</li>
<li>Role of vitamin C in wound healing</li>
<li>Keloid</li>
</ol>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">HEMODYNAMIC DISORDER</h3>
<h5>Long Questions</h5>
<ol>
<li>Edema, etiopathogenesis of generalized edema, clinical significance of cerebral and pulmonary edema</li>
<li>Define thrombosis, write in detail about the pathogenesis, causes, morphology and fate of thrombus</li>
<li>Define shock, discuss in detail the pathogenesis of septic shock, describe the morphology of kidneys and lungs affected by shock</li>
<li>Define, classify , pathogenicity & morphology of shock</li>
<li>Define and classify shock. Discuss in detail about septic shock</li>
</ol>
<h5>Short Questions</h5>
<ol>
<li>Edema pathogenesis</li>
<li>Cardiac edema</li>
<li>Thrombogenesis</li>
<li>Virchow’s triad</li>
<li>Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome</li>
<li>Difference between thrombus and blood clot</li>
<li>Embolism</li>
<li>Thromboembolism</li>
<li>Types of embolism, write on caissons disease</li>
<li>Fat embolism</li>
<li>Air embolism</li>
<li>Gangrene</li>
<li>Morphology of infarction</li>
<li>Amniotic fluid embolism</li>
<li>Gross and microscopic feature of infarct</li>
<li>Difference between the dry and wet gangrene</li>
<li>Gangrene – pathogenesis</li>
<li>Pathogenesis of shock</li>
<li>Septic shock</li>
<li>Define hyperemia and congestion</li>
<li>Heart failure cells</li>
<li>Anticoagulants</li>
<li>Lines of zahn</li>
<li>State four difference between dry and wet gangrene</li>
<li>Name the stages of shock</li>
<li>Gamma gandy bodies</li>
<li>Enlist four important sequelae for Thrombosis</li>
</ol>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">GENETIC DISORDERS</h3>
<h5>Short Questions</h5>
<ol>
<li>Mention four X-linked recessive disorders</li>
<li>X linked diseases</li>
<li>Hypercholesterolemia</li>
<li>Niemann pick disease</li>
<li>Gaucher’s disease</li>
<li>Glycogen storage disorders</li>
<li>Sex chromatin</li>
<li>Down syndrome</li>
<li>Trisomy 21</li>
<li>Klinefelter’s syndrome</li>
<li>Turner’s syndrome</li>
<li>Give two examples of autosomal recessive disorders</li>
<li>Mention 4 X-linked recessive disorders</li>
<li>Gaucher’s cell</li>
<li>Special stain to diagnose Gaucher’s disease</li>
<li>Enumerate 4 types of chromosomal rearrangements</li>
<li>Clinical features of trisomy 21</li>
<li>Trisomy 18</li>
<li>Name two trisomy syndromes</li>
<li>FISH</li>
<li>Enumerate two common cytogenetic disorders involving Sex Chromosomes</li>
</ol>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">DISEASES OF IMMUNITY</h3>
<h5>Long Questions</h5>
<ol>
<li>Define auto, iso, allo , xenografts, factors influencing allograft rejection, types and mechanism of allograft rejection</li>
<li>Classify primary immunodeficiency syndrome, details about AIDS</li>

<h5>Clinical Scenario</h5>
<ol>
<li>40 year female presents with post coital bleeding and foul smelling discharge per vagina. She lost 15% wt in 2 months, with loss of appetite. a) What is your diagnosis ? b) What etiopathogenesis of this condition? c) What are the morphological features?</li>
<li>A 60 year old postmenopausal anorexic, cachectic woman has an ulcerated and friable cervix that bleeds on touch. These features were accompanied by foul smelling vaginal discharge. a) What is your diagnosis? b) Discuss in detail the aetiopathogenesis and morphological features of your diagnosis. c) Enlist the investigations that will enable diagnosis</li>
<li>20 years female H/o pain, swelling, tenderness over lower and of right femur since 3 months. Suddenly developed breathlessness during her treatment and died, clinical autopsy conducted. Answer the following: a) What is your diagnosis? b) Mention two investigations to arrive at diagnosis? c) Aetio pathogenesis of the lesion? d) Gross and Microscopic picture of the lesion? e) Mention two autopsy confirmed lesions leading to death?</li>
<li>A 35 years, old man was admitted with history of painless cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. He had history of loss of weight, fever and night sweating and was found to have cutaneous anergy. No hepatosplenomegaly. a) What is your most probable diagnosis? b) Give the classification of the condition. c) Describe the morphology of any two types.</li>
<li>A 50 years old man collapses suddenly while climbing the stairs with severe chest pain and profuse sweating. a) What is your clinical diagnosis? b) Discuss the aetiopathogenesis of the condition. c) What are the complications that may follow the condition?</li>
<li>A 12 year old boy presented with fever, oliguria and high coloured urine. He had sore throat three weeks back. i) What is your probable diagnosis? ii) Describe the etiopathogenesis of the condition iii) What are the relevant investigations?</li>
<li>A 50 year old man with complains of severe chest pain and sweating. a) What is the most possible diagnosis for this patient? b) Enlist the risk factors and discuss in detail the etiopathogenesis and complications of this disease. c) Enlist the biochemical tests and their role in diagnosis of this disease.</li>
<li>Thirteen year old female child had massive edema with puffiness of face with decreased urine output. a. What is the most probable diagnosis ? b. What can be the most probable renal pathology in this child ? c. Write in detail about minimal change disease.</li>
<li>44 year old nulliparous women presented with hard, fixed non tender mass of about 6x4x4 cm in the upper outer quadrant of right breast with axillary lymphadenopathy. a) What is your probably diagnosis. b) Discuss in detail the prognostic & predictive factors of your diagnosis.</li>
<li>8 Yr Old boy with old scar of scabies skin lesion, with history of Haematuria, Oliguria and Puffiness of face. a) What is your probable diagnosis. b) Etiopathogeneisis and laboratory investigations.</li>
<li>50 Yr old Male with painless firm Testicular swelling, with loss of testicular sensation. a) What is your probable Diagnosis. b) Discuss classification and Etiopathogenesis.</li>
<li>47 yrs old male presented with acute onset of dyspnea, profuse sweating and chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. Lab investigation revealed elevated troponin – T. What is your diagnosis, pathogenesis and morphology of the condition?</li>
<li>A sixty year old male presented with anaemia, loss of weight, persistent abdominal pain, abdominal distension and vomiting. Upper GI endoscopy and biopsy done. a) What is the probable diagnosis? b) Discuss the etiopathogenesis and morphology of the disease.</li>
<li>65/M presented with bleeding PR. Colonoscopy revealed a hard mass in rectosigmoid. What is your diagnosis?</li>
<li>50 years / Male admitted in emergency care with chest pain, profuse sweating and Rapid pulse. What is your diagnosis? Describe the Etiopathogenesis, Morphology and Complications of the above mentioned disease.</li>
<li>A 3yrs old child was hospitalized for the complaints of fever and passing smoky urine. The child had recovered from sore throat a week ago. What is your diagnosis? Describe the etiopathogenesis, morphology and laboratory findings of this condition.</li>
<li>75 year male presented with dyspnea and sweating of sudden onset. He is a known hypertensive and diabetic for 15 years. On examination he has weak pulse. What is the diagnosis? Write about pathogenesis of the above disorder. Write in detail about the morphological changes that occur.</li>
<li>55 year old post menopausal women presented with hard lump 6 x 6 cm in upper outer quadrant of left breast. FNA – revealed cluster of pleomorphic cells. a) What is your clinical diagnosis? Discuss the etiopathogenesis, molecular mechanism of carcinogenesis of the disease. Discuss about prognostic and predictive factors of the disease.</li>
<li>A 50 year old male presents with cough, dyspnoea, and intermittent haemoptysis for two months along with loss of weight and appetite. He is a chronic smoker for the past 3 decades. CT chest revealed mass lesion in the right lobe of lung. a) What is your probable diagnosis? b) Discuss in detail the classification, morphological features and the Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with it.</li>
</ol>
